title: Comments made on Images on MRs don’t show up on changes tab
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

In MRs, image threads don't appear in the Changes tab, although you can create them there. They are only visible in the Overview tab.

![Video](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/aea5d200b26257248ef512b39184ae44/CleanShot_2020-05-21_at_14.02.05.mp4)

### Steps to reproduce

1. Go to a MR with an Image added
1. Try to leave a comment in the image
1. Thread doesn't show up in Changes tab
1. Go to Overview tab
1. Thread is there

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/andr3/meet.andr3.net/-/merge_requests/24/diffs#diff-content-f8aeeb2fcb79e3855b444ae85b432fe2b7dd2a7d

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Thread only shows in Overview tab.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Thread also shows in the Changes tab


### Further info

**This should also solve the problem** of threads being left in the Commits page not showing up in the MR changes.

epic.title: Fix experience of using images in MRs

title: Remove one block type relationship from issue links
description:
Issues can block others with two relationship types, `{ TYPE_BLOCKS => 1, TYPE_IS_BLOCKED_BY => 2}`:  

| source_issue | block_type | target_issue |
| ---      |  ------  |---------:|
| issue_1   | TYPE_BLOCKS   | issue_2   |
| issue_3 | TYPE_IS_BLOCKED_BY | issue_1 |  

On the example above `issue_1` is blocking two other issues using two different types of block.

The extra relation type adds complexity when querying for blocking/blocked issues as can be seen on `IssueLink` class.  

If possible we should consider using just one kind of blocking type to make queries simpler and a bit faster.
We will still be able to identify if an issue is `blocked` or `blocking` using the `target_id` and `source_id` keys.  

This task will need migrations. ~~We can get rid of the relation that has less records on database, which is this case is
`TYPE_BLOCKS => 1`~~ We can migrate records with `link_type = 2` to have `link_type = 1` and stop saving records with `link_type = 2`:  

``` sql
gitlabhq_production=> SELECT COUNT(*) FROM issue_links WHERE link_type = 1 \g
 count 
-------
 10410
(1 row)

gitlabhq_production=> SELECT COUNT(*) FROM issue_links WHERE link_type = 2 \g
 count 
-------
 26218
(1 row)

```  

For more context check the discussion on https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/34665#note_365697703

title: Rename default Browser Performance Testing job name (breaking change)
description:
This is a follow up from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/34634.

The default job name for [Browser Performance Testing](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/merge_requests/browser_performance_testing.html) is currently named just `performance` in it's [template](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/ci/templates/Verify/Browser-Performance.gitlab-ci.yml). After several attempts in the MR to change it to the intended `browser_performance` it was concluded to not be feasible currently to do this as well as maintain backwards compatibility with users who are using the `performance` job currently.

In addition to this we should also update the `PERFORMANCE_DISABLED` [AutoDevOps environment variable](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/topics/autodevops/customize.html#disable-jobs) to `BROWSER_PERFORMANCE_DISABLED`.

As such, we'll look to do this later as a breaking change making sure to notify users with enough time.

title: Change "Could not retrieve pipeline status" error state when the pipeline was just created
description:
## Description

This is very similar to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/216048#note_373214445 and share the same states. When you create a MR, the pipeline takes time to get created. we show an error message because there is no pipeline for this commit yet. We have no way to determine (yet) if the pipeline is currently getting processed, if there is a problem with the pipeline creation OR if you have an external CI solution and are waiting after that response.

The original message that was shown when this issue appeared was:
`Could not retrieve the pipeline status. For troubleshooting steps, read the documentation.`

But just like the previous issue, we added a state for when no CI config was found and Pipelines must succeed was turned on. Which means that we now see: No pipeline has been run for this commit
on .com. Both of these messages had the error red icon which led to thinking there was a problem with the MR pipeline, when actually we are just waiting for it to be created.

## Solution

Short term, we want to add a generic message along the lines of `We are monitoring for pipelines to be created for this MR.`

## Screenshots

### Current Problem

![Screen_Shot_2020-07-02_at_2.03.50_PM](/uploads/49a6af86ed22c0a38c9393abde54409d/Screen_Shot_2020-07-02_at_2.03.50_PM.png)

### Proposed solution

![Screen_Shot_2020-07-06_at_2.44.08_PM](/uploads/0fd682ef0c8afd98c32f055cbdf1ea81/Screen_Shot_2020-07-06_at_2.44.08_PM.png)

title: Rename approval status blacklisted to denied
description:
## Summary

Users can configure approved/denied licenses through License Compliance configuration page. This page uses [managed licenses api end point](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/managed_licenses.html) . Api end point has field called approval status. Approval status can be either `blacklisted` or `approved`. 

Since Whitelist/Blacklist have connotations about value and map to racial terms, we should rename it to `denied` . In that way terminology will be consistent with UI. 

## Proposal 

- [ ] Support both blacklisted and denied as `approval_status` for [managed licenses api end point](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/managed_licenses.html)
- [ ] Currently when we deny/approve license via License configuration page, we send `blacklisted` in POST request to api end point. We need to change payload to send `denied` instead of `blaclisted` since api will support `denied` (see screenshot below)
- [ ] Migrate license policy data from blacklisted to denied  
- [ ] Make sure denied licenses are blocked when they are introduced in MR. (this is just to a check changing blacklisted  -> denied didn't break functionality)
- [ ] Deprecate blacklisted approval status (this could be done in another issue)

![image](/uploads/e32da798a2b1b4194101eb5a10ac9f51/image.png)

## Implementation Plan

* [ ] Remove usage of [LEGACY_CLASSIFICATION_STATUS](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6dfb81530a1e43eb9f08bf7c1a1c7c9bb76dbb55/ee/app/models/software_license_policy.rb#L9-12).
* [ ] Update the #create endpoint of the API to refer to the new terms [source](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6dfb81530a1e43eb9f08bf7c1a1c7c9bb76dbb55/ee/lib/api/managed_licenses.rb#L62-63).
* [ ] Update #update action of API to refer to new terms [source](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6dfb81530a1e43eb9f08bf7c1a1c7c9bb76dbb55/ee/lib/api/managed_licenses.rb#L89-90)
* [ ] Update API endpoints to map from the old terms to the new terms.
* [ ] Replace usages of `approval_status` with `classification` (stretch goal)

## Involved components

- [Managed licenses api](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/managed_licenses.html)
- [License Compliance configuration](https://gitlab.com/help/user/compliance/license_compliance/index)
 
## Testing

Managed license api and License Compliance configuration work as usual

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Issues that we want to do but are not planned right now. Open for contribution from the community.

title: Replace fa-git icons with GitLab SVG 'link' icon
description:
As part of the effort to replace FontAwesome icons with GitLab SVGs we need to use the [link](http://gitlab-org.gitlab.io/gitlab-svgs/?q=link) icon instead of the FontAwesome variants.

title: Remove orchestrator package from common analyzer
description:
### Problem to solve

We've already deprecated the DinD mode and switched to non-DinD by default. Orchestrator layer should be removed after we remove `DS_DISABLE_DIND`, `SAST_DISABLE_DIND` variables from [templates](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/ci/templates/Security/Dependency-Scanning.gitlab-ci.yml)

### Intended users

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)

### User experience goal

Orchestrator layer should no longer used by Common library.

### Proposal

- Remove orchestrator from common library 

### Implementation Plan

- Update common library
  - [x] Remove [orchestrator package](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common/-/tree/master/orchestrator) from common analyzer
- Update READMEs
  - [x] Add deprecation note to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dependency-scanning/
  - [x] Add deprecation note to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/sast/

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

### Permissions and Security

No change.

### Documentation

* remove [SAST DinD documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/sast/index.html#enabling-docker-in-docker), related env variables and any other related section.
* remove [Dependency Scanning DinD documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/dependency_scanning/#enabling-docker-in-docker), related env variables and any other related section.

See [implementation plan](#implementation-plan)

### Availability & Testing

DinD for SAST and Dependency Scanning are no longer tested. The test projects are used to test the no-DinD setup where each analyzer runs in its own CI job. In particular, the `master` branch of all test projects is used to check the default no-DinD setup.

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

SAST and Dependency Scanning no longer support DinD mode.

### What is the type of buyer?

~"GitLab Ultimate" 

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

This impacts:

* ~"group::composition analysis"
* ~"group::static analysis"

### Links / references

Release post for planned removal: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/merge_requests/52499/diffs

title: GitLab use the previous license instead of the newest license on the system after upgrading
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

After customers upgrade their Self-Managed GitLab instance, the system activates the previous license instead of the newest license on installed. 

### Steps to reproduce

1. Have a license installed that's close to license end term
1. Renew the license and install on the system (the old license is still valid)
1. Upgrade the system
1. When the instance restart, observe that the previous license is loaded instead the latest
1. The renewed license get activated at the start date

### Example Project

(If possible, please create an example project here on GitLab.com that exhibits the problematic behavior, and link to it here in the bug report)

(If you are using an older version of GitLab, this will also determine whether the bug is fixed in a more recent version)

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Confusing license switch. The new license was able to upload but the system choose the previous one upon upgrade.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

One of the below:

- License with future start date should not be uploaded successfully.
- License with future start date can be uploaded successfully, and the system provide banner or information that the license will be automatically activated on the start date; and the old license display banner informing that customer has `Users over license` but it will be reset with the new license

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

(Paste any relevant logs - please use code blocks (```) to format console output,
logs, and code as it's tough to read otherwise.)

### Output of checks

Customer upgraded to GitLab 13.0.1

### Possible fixes

(If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem)

### Workaround

Restart the system

### Affecting:

- https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/162165

title: Introduce group license compliance - Provide side panel data for list page - Backend
description:
Parent issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/202224

# Problem to solve

The work described in this issue is to provide the necessary data from the ~backend so that the following panels can be loaded in the ~frontend.

![screenshot-2020-07-02-1593725287](/uploads/656261b1b5243abdddb7b3c0c9b2a4b3/screenshot-2020-07-02-1593725287.png)

![screenshot-2020-07-02-1593725298](/uploads/5337fe39bd8f34a8d831fbc6f7766857/screenshot-2020-07-02-1593725298.png)

# Implementation Plan:

* [ ] Create a groups/licenses controller.
* [ ] Add an `#index` action that serves the JSON below.
* [ ] Update/Create metrics dashboard to keep track of the time it takes to load this endpoint.
* [ ] Find a suitable worst case size for the max # of a projects that a group may have.
* [ ] Test out load times for the worst case scenario.
* [ ] Research/document opportunities to aggregate report data into de-normalized report tables.

The first iteration of the ~backend work will focus on aggregating the data from the in memory reports. We may need to utilize the reactive cache but we'll pay attention to worst case scenarios and look for opportunities to measure potential performance problems. We'll be mindful about areas where it may make sense to pre-compute or aggregate this data in flattened report structures that may possibly be stored in the database for the next iteration.

The initial implementation will provide relative paths to the configuration and project pages so that we can render the data needed for the side panel.


E.g.

GET /gitlab-org/gitlab/-/licenses.json

```json
{
 projects: [
  {
    id: 1,
    project_path: '/-/projects/1/licenses`,
    configuration_path: '/-/projects/1/security/configuration',
    configured: true
  },
  {
    id: 2,
    project_path: '/-/projects/2/licenses`,
    configuration_path: '/-/projects/1/security/configuration',
    configured: false
  },
 ]
}

```

Main issue:

* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/202224

This issue follows the sub-issue convention described in:

* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/issues/4588

title: Release evidence for report artifacts links to nonexistent evidence
Docs - product feedback: Release evidence collection
description:
### Problem to solve

The documentation for including report artifacts as release evidence states that both `artifacts:paths` and `artifacts:reports` must be specified to enable collection (see https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/doc/user/project/releases/index.md#L383).


### Further details

This does not appear to be true.  As demonstrated in the example project at https://gitlab.com/aarongoldenthal/release-evidence-test, release evidence is collected from the predefined security templates that do not include `artifacts:paths` (see release 0.1.0).

title: Release evidence collection results in test results from inconsistent pipelines
description:
### Summary

Release evidence collection of test results, as implemented in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/32773, results in test results collected from different pipelines depending on release creation mechanism and timing, and in some cases from incomplete pipelines.

### Steps to reproduce

Create a release using the web UI or API as described below.  The examples below are do not include future releases.

### Example Project

An example project is at https://gitlab.com/aarongoldenthal/release-evidence-test, with the various cases outlined below.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

If a tag and release are created together via the GitLab UI, then the release evidence is taken from the last pipeline (in the example project above this was a push pipeline), as expected.

If a tag is added to an existing commit (whose last push pipeline is complete), and in that pipeline the release is created via the API, the release evidence is taken from the tag pipeline. The evidence is pulled at the point of release creation, even if that pipeline is not complete, and it pulls only the evidence available at that point (e.g. if the release is created after the test stage then it pulls test results from that pipeline, but if the release is created before the test stage or with no test stage then no results are returned).

In addition to this creating at least non-intuitive, and arguably inconsistent results (since API and UI created releases result in different evidence), the built-in security jobs are not run in tag pipelines.  So, they are included in release evidence created from web UI, but not the API.  

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Releases should:

- Produce consistent release evidence when created via any available means
- Allow creation from a tag pipeline and include the appropriate release evidence without having to repeat the tests in that pipeline
- Pull release evidence from the last push pipeline for a branch that includes the tag, and wait until that pipeline completes if it is not when the release is created.  This allows inclusion of the predefined security and other template jobs, and other test jobs, and only run in pipelines where content is changed.
  - The release evidence could be pulled from the tag pipeline once complete, but in that case the predefined security and other template jobs need to run in tag pipelines as well (which can add a lot of compute time).

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com.

milestone.title: Backlog

title: Environments: Allow to DELETE an environment without STOPPING it
description:
### Release notes
In 15.1, we added a `force` option to the Stop and environment API. This allows you to effectively delete an active environment without running the specified `on_stop` jobs.

### Problem to solve

When `on_stop` is specified, stopping an environment will schedule a delete job to be run.

I need to delete some stale environments from GitLab because they got out of control and slow down our GitLab. I do NOT want GitLab to execute the delete jobs as this would: 

1. Schedule hundreds of thousands of jobs in GitLab Runners
2. Be potentially destructive to these (non-GitLab) deployments.

### Intended users

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/

* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager) 

### User experience goal

The user should be able to use Environments and Deployments pages without killing GitLab server. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/19724

### Proposal

Allow me to DELETE an environment without STOPPING it.

### Links / references

@dosuken123 @markglenfletcher 

Related: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/19724

title: Could not retrieve the pipeline status. For troubleshooting steps, read the documentation (GitLab CI)
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

This bug happens on the GitLab.com interface.
We’re using Gitlab with Gitlab CI on a shared, free plan, with public workers. Our mode of operation is to encourage developers to work in Git branches and keep 1 merge request opened per branch, with it transitioning between MR open/close state during review iterations. We notice that after reopening a merge request, the Gitlab pipeline will run but the status is not reflected in the merge request view (main screen).

### Steps to reproduce

Outlined in comment https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/225710#note_675913518

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

GitLab does not show an accurate pipeline status to merge request page. 
We noticed that in a flow of:
- Developer opened an MR “X”
- Reviewer reviewed it, suggested changes, closed MR “X”
- Developer pushes commits to address change requests
- Developer waits to see a CI job to finish successfully (GitLab -> CI -> Pipelines tab and also GitLab -> Ci -> Jobs tab appear to show the right status for the most recently pushed commits)
- Developer reopened MR “X”
- Gitlab very often ends with this error message: “Could not retrieve the pipeline status. For troubleshooting steps, read the documentation”.
- When we go to “Pipelines” for this MR, the pipeline status is correctly reflected. We noticed that this issue persists for very many hours.

We noticed that the possible workaround is to push a commit when an MR is opened. For example, some MRs left opened, but later pre-merged with “master”, get out of this state.

Leaving the merge request open overnight (and then pushing a few more commits to the branch) also solved the problem.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Should link the pipeline status (success/fail) to merge request page immediately, instead of needing to wait an excessive amount of time or having to push additional commits.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![image](/uploads/f75a00c1262932fba1417698abb8e7e8/image.png)

```
Could not retrieve the pipeline status. For troubleshooting steps, read the documentation.
```
The documentation link points to [here](https://gitlab.com/help/user/project/merge_requests/reviewing_and_managing_merge_requests.md#troubleshooting).

### Proposal

A `isPostMerge` MR  is checking for `mr.ciStatus` which is `undefined` always and we return an error message to the user. We should add a handler for the CI status and return the status of a merge pipeline instead.

`app/assets/javascripts/vue_merge_request_widget/components/mr_widget_pipeline_container.vue`

```js
hasCIStatus() {
  return this.isPostMerge ? !isEmpty(this.mr.mergePipeline.details.status) : this.mr.ciStatus;
},
```

Also may need to make `app/assets/javascripts/vue_merge_request_widget/components/mr_widget_pipeline.vue` prop `ciStatus` accept both `String` and `Boolean` types.

title: Evaluate limits on Max file size indexed in Advanced Search
description:
### Problem we want to solve
When users are searching across projects in Advanced Search they will not see results from files larger than 1mb. 
These Larger files, while less common, are maybe some of the stronger use cases for Code Search. 

### Proposal
We should review the files sizes of the items indexed to look at percentages and base the size limitations off of the 95% range. 
Alternatively  we should consider match the size limitations for Gitlab (default 10mb). 

### Other Information

[https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/general-recommendations.
](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/general-recommendations.)

[https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch-py/issues/1079](htmlhttps://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch-py/issues/1079)

[Maybe there are better ways to process large files. ](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/search-aggregations-metrics-top-hits-aggregation.html)

epic.title: Advanced Global Search Improve and Optimize Recall

title: Fix zero-downtime upgrade process/instructions for multi-node Geo deployments
description:
We have [observed downtime while following the zero-downtime upgrade instructions for multi-node Geo deployments](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/geo/replication/geo_validation_tests.html#geo-validation-tests).  This issue covers identifying and fixing the blockers to zero-downtime, and updating zero-downtime upgrade instructions.

1. Identify at which [step(s)](https://docs.gitlab.com/omnibus/update/README.html#multi-node--ha-deployment-with-geo-premium-only) downtime occurs during an upgrade.  This might involve using HAProxy dashboards, real-time server logs and/or other means to get live feedback (end-to-end tests have a delay related to built-in waits inherent to these types of tests).

1. Fix any blockers to zero-downtime upgrades.

1. Test revised zero-downtime upgrade process on current and previous versions of GitLab (the versions with version-specific instructions available on docs.gitlab.com)

1. Revise zero-downtime instructions for current GitLab version, and update instructions for the previous GitLab versions tested in previous step (either with corrected instructions for zero-downtime upgrades or removal of instructions if zero-downtime is not possible for those versions)

epic.title: Geo Upgrade Testing

title: Add MAU data for Ecosystem Usage Ping
description:
## Data needed

Currently, we only collect [the number of active services per integration type](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/usage_data.rb#L348), but we'd also like to know the _number of users_ of each integration.

I'd like to add another set of data along the lines of `projects_FOO_users`. This should be a unique count of the number of members of each project that has an active service.

## Links/resources

- `def services_usage` in `usage_data.rb` - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/usage_data.rb#L348
- 

/cc @leipert

title: Package Detail: Update the "Version" tab to be "Other Versions"
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

Currently on the package registry, when you're viewing the detail view of a package, you are presented with the details of a specific version. There is a tab navigation element that allows you to see other versions of the package.  Currently, the label can be confusing, implying that you are looking at a vague package detail, and need to navigate to see the different versions.

### Intended users

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)
* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager) 

### User experience goal

Improve the experience of understanding package details by clarifying that you're looking at a single version and can navigate to other versions.


### Proposal

Change the copy on the "Versions" tab to read: "Other versions"

| Updated Tab Copy |
|---|
|![225674_Update_Version_to_Other_Versions](/uploads/da4a96931a4f73829778b43cb68e4d1c/225674_Update_Version_to_Other_Versions.png)|

### Further details

By clarifying that the tab represents navigation to **other** versions, the number next to the tab title **must** be the count of other packages, excluding the current package being viewed. 

### Permissions and Security

<!-- What permissions are required to perform the described actions? Are they consistent with the existing permissions as documented for users, groups, and projects as appropriate? Is the proposed behavior consistent between the UI, API, and other access methods (e.g. email replies)?
Consider adding checkboxes and expectations of users with certain levels of membership https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html

* [ ] Add expected impact to Reporter (20) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Developer (30) members 
* [ ] Add expected impact to Maintainer (40) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Owner (50) members -->

### Documentation

If we mention or explain the "Versions" tab, we should update the copy to include "Other versions" and clarify that the other versions are exclusive of the version of the package you're currently looking at.

### Availability & Testing

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

title: [VSA] Median data is being requested unnecessarily for hidden stages
description:
### Problem to solve

On `gitlab-org`, some Value Stream Analytics (VSA) stages are hidden, however the median data is still loaded.

### Further details

This was reported in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/225405#note_371403582.

### Proposal

In Value Stream Analytics, do not request the median data for hidden stages. changes we need to make are in the following places:
- [Stage median data](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/cc29e1bac0ceb5b7c937152629acc90eac347ec7/ee/app/assets/javascripts/analytics/cycle_analytics/store/actions.js#L76)
- [Duration chart data](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/analytics/cycle_analytics/store/modules/duration_chart/actions.js#L34)
- [Duration chart median](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/analytics/cycle_analytics/store/modules/duration_chart/actions.js#L72)

In those locations we are looping over all the stages, then fetching their data instead we should use the [`activeStages` getter](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/cc29e1bac0ceb5b7c937152629acc90eac347ec7/ee/app/assets/javascripts/analytics/cycle_analytics/store/actions.js#L127) which excludes the `hidden` stages.

title: Refactor GitlabRoutingHelper Snippet methods
description:
## Summary

The `GitlabRoutingHelper` provides us with some super useful methods for getting routes for various models, but it would benefit from some refactoring.

In particular, we have multiple method definitions for url/path variations of the same route - which could be combined into one and instead pass in a `:only_path` option

## Improvements
The following are the methods I've identified so far that could be combined:

- `gitlab_raw_snippet_path`
- `gitlab_snippet_notes_path`
- `gitlab_snippet_note_path`
- `gitlab_toggle_award_emoji_snippet_note_path`
- `gitlab_toggle_award_emoji_snippet_path`

## Risks

We'd need to also modify each place where these methods are called, to instead call the `*_url` variant with an `only_path: true` option

## Involved components
At the time of writing, the following files will be involved:

**`gitlab_raw_snippet_path`**
- `app/helpers/snippet_blob_presenter.rb:22`
- `app/helpers/snippets_helper.rb:16`
- `app/helpers/gitlab_routing_helper.rb`
- `app/helpers/gitlab_routing_helper_spec.rb`

**`gitlab_snippet_notes_path`**
- `app/helpers/notes_helper.rb:105`
- `app/helpers/notes_helper.rb:136`

**`gitlab_snippet_note_path`**
- `app/helpers/notes_helper.rb:115`

**`gitlab_toggle_award_emoji_snippet_note_path`**
- `app/helpers/award_emoji_helper.rb:10`


## Optional: Intended side effects

This will reduce the number of lines in `GitlabRoutingHelper` and the duplication of code, which will make it easier to read

### Problem to solve

When looking at a package detail page, the header area contains several important pieces of metadata related to the package. Currently, the ordering of the metadata can make it difficult to quickly digest.

| Current UI |
|---|

Package Registry - In the group registry view, make the project UI moment easier to read and relevant
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

When a user is looking at a group level registry, we display the package's project as a data-point on each individual list item. This helps users stay organized and understand the breakdown of different registries. 

However, for users operating in a complicated group structure, this information can become unmanageable and difficult to discern.

| Current UI |
|---|
|![Screen_Shot_2020-07-02_at_12.20.12](/uploads/6b66dcbb7682faaadec422f3a859494a/Screen_Shot_2020-07-02_at_12.20.12.png)|

### Intended users

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Allison (Application Ops)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#allison-application-ops) 
* [Priyanka (Platform Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#priyanka-platform-engineer)

### User experience goal

Display the project data related to a specific package in the list view in a manageable and human way.


### Proposal

Update the design of the "project" data points in the list view so that it displays the project data relative to the group the user is viewing: 

| Updated project UI update |
|---|
|![Package_Registry_Group_View__1_](/uploads/6201db67f6c9aa57ecff5fdbc121fed0/Package_Registry_Group_View__1_.png)|

Because the project name (or subgroup/project name) is a more flexible UI object, I also suggest we move it to the end of the package metadata line. This would mean the package type will come second instead of last.

### Further details

For most of our users, the "Project" datapoint will only show the project that is a child of the group they're currently viewing.

| UI With Single child project |
|---|
|![Screen_Shot_2020-07-02_at_12.21.12](/uploads/b55699424575f8b1066f979b16a73258/Screen_Shot_2020-07-02_at_12.21.12.png)|

For some users, they'll find a package that is contained in a project that is a child of a sub-group. That subgroup is a child of the group the user is currently looking at.

| UI with single sub-group project child relationship |
|---|
|![Screen_Shot_2020-07-02_at_12.23.27](/uploads/955cbf96cde1e463c56b90eacf729307/Screen_Shot_2020-07-02_at_12.23.27.png)|

In our rarest case, users will view a package that has a more complex hierarchy. After the first Sub-Group is displayed, an ellipses icon will be used similar to the breadcrumb navigation to show all of the n+2 subgroups.

| UI with multiple subgroups included |
|---|
|![Screen_Shot_2020-07-02_at_12.25.49](/uploads/45d42ad064b2aac58d38266758760c9e/Screen_Shot_2020-07-02_at_12.25.49.png)|


We should also include a tooltip on hover that displays the entire path of the related project from instance -> group -> subgroup -> project

| Tooltip hover example |
|---|
|![image](/uploads/c974aedd6080c357a6adb69f240c3d7c/image.png)|

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

### Permissions and Security

N/a

### Documentation

Updating screenshots in the documentation may be needed when discussing the group level view. 

@nmezzopera @trizzi - If we go with this breakdown, do you think the documentation should include a note explaining the elipses icon will show all of the sub-groups between the first sub-group and the project name?

### Availability & Testing

n/a

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

Users will be able to more easily identify the project/sub-group relationship of a package compared to the group they're viewing. They won't be forced to see the hierarchy of all the groups above the currently viewed (sub) group.

### What is the type of buyer?

n/a

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

No

title: Add a simple link to read the release note
description:
### Problem to solve
Improve user experience for administrator who need to read the release note

### Intended users

* [Parker (Product Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#parker-product-manager)
* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Presley (Product Designer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#presley-product-designer)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager) 

### User experience goal
As someone who needs to find and read the release note quickly.


### Proposal
Add a simple link to go on the appropriate page.


### Further details
As an administrator I often see new release available (update available or update asap).
![gitlab-version](/uploads/d6ddbb0ab691339f5c5f356c2ff8ed99/gitlab-version.png)

I don't have any problem on this, but I don't know what's new or what's critical. For knowledge this information's, I need to  looking for the appropriate page on your website, and it's just boring...
I know that my feature proposal, is very minor, but I think that was a good idea, well ... I think so.

title: Incorrect issues URLs in Value Stream Analytics dashboard for subgroups
description:
### Summary

URLs for the issues in Value Stream Analytics dashboard are incorrectly formed. They seem to be missing the "groups/:group_slug" portion of the URL.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Open a Value Stream Analytics Dashboard for any subgroup (so, not a top level), (e.g., https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/growth/-/analytics/value_stream_analytics )
1. Try to open any issue from the dashboard
1. Observe 404 error

E.g., from the Growth Dashboard the links generated look like `https://gitlab.com/growth/product/-/issues/1592` instead of `https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/growth/product/-/issues/1592` (missing `gitlab-org`)

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/growth/-/analytics/value_stream_analytics

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

404 error when trying to open any issue links from a subgrpoup Value Stream Analytics dashboard

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Links should lead to an issue

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![Screen_Shot_2020-07-02_at_8.32.45_AM](/uploads/1679db4426f1c3d6018fe64e9144eaa0/Screen_Shot_2020-07-02_at_8.32.45_AM.png)

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com.

### Possible fixes

Add the missing "groups/:group_slug" portion of the URL.

title: Enable code_navigation_references feature flag by default
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## What

Enable the `:code_navigation_references` feature flag introduced in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217392 by default.

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::source code" 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_create_source-code`
- Best individual to reach out to: @patrickbajao 

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

LSIF json files will still be generated for those projects with code intelligence enabled.

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

No LSIF json files will be generated.

## Beta groups/projects

If applicable, any groups/projects that are happy to have this feature turned on early. Some organizations may wish to test big changes they are interested in with a small subset of users ahead of time for example.

- `gitlab-org/gitlab-shell` project
- `gitlab-org/gitlab-workhorse` project

## Roll Out Steps

- [x] Enable on staging
- [x] Test on staging
- [x] Ensure that documentation has been updated
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com for individual groups/projects listed above and verify behaviour
- [x] Announce on the issue an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com by running chatops command in `#production`
- [x] Cross post chatops slack command to `#support_gitlab-com` ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#where-to-run-commands)) and in your team channel
- [x] Announce on the issue that the flag has been enabled
- [x] Enable feature flag by default

epic.title: 🌀 Code intelligence MVC (jump to definition, find references)

title: Improve memory and file size of LSIF json with references
description:
In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217392, we added support for finding references which means we will be adding `references` to the JSON file we generate.

That will increase memory usage and the file size of the generated JSON files (even when zipped).

We have an existing caching in file mechanism so we can use that to save up some RAM. Look into a way to improve file size of the generated JSON file if possible.

epic.title: 🌀 Code intelligence MVC (jump to definition, find references)

title: Display accurate reason why suggestion is not applicable on apply
description:
The following discussion from !34149 should be addressed:

- [ ] @pedroms started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/34149#note_371908396):  (+1 comment)

    > @patrickbajao 📝 **Text**: When a user merges an MR and doesn't refresh the page, the suggestions that weren't applied still show an enabled `Apply suggestion` button. I assume we are not updating these buttons in real-time when an MR is merged. If that is true, can we change the error message that appears when the user then presses one of those buttons, so that it uses the same tooltip text that we show when the button is disabled?
    > 
    > ![CleanShot_2020-07-01_at_17.47.17](/uploads/597cd7ebdc94f7f77faf8763fbffb617/CleanShot_2020-07-01_at_17.47.17.png)
    > 
    > To be clear, what I'm suggesting is having `This merge request was merged. To apply this suggestion, edit this file directly.` as the error message in that alert component.

---

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/219455, `Suggestion#inapplicable_reason` was added. That can be used here to display the same message when applying suggestion fails.

title: [Step 4] Update namespace statistics after snippets update
description:
At the moment, when a snippet is updated, only the project statistics get updated, not the namespace ones. This is because we didn't include the `snippets_size` statistics inside [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/models/project_statistics.rb#L16). That would make that any change in the `snippets_size` triggers an update in the namespace statistics.

We didn't do this at first by default in order not to hurt performance, the discussion is https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/commit/ec39a1d63d8a7952930442165f1ad828939749b2#note_367932364.

Nevertheless, we can't use the other resource we [have](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/models/concerns/update_project_statistics.rb) because snippet repositories can be updated directly through git, therefore no callback in any ActiveRecord model will be called. Besides, with the snippet we can update the title, for example, and that shouldn't trigger and update.

In this issue, we'll introduce the feature flag `namespace_snippets_size_stat` to include the `snippets_size` inside https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/models/project_statistics.rb#L16 and trigger an automatic update.

title: [Step 1] Add documentation about how to reduce snippet repository size
description:
Since snippets repository size will be part of the namespace's quota, it's important to inform users how to try to reduce that size. Even more when we don't have (yet) any housekeeping mechanism over those repositories.

We need to add some documentation about this. Maybe https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/snippets.html#versioned-snippets should be the place to include it. Since snippet repositories don't allow to create other branches nor tags, there are only a few things we can do for this task. The necessary info is in https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/repository/reducing_the_repo_size_using_git.html#purge-files-from-repository-history.

I'm not sure whether we should link to that section or rewrite the information there and show only the possible things users can perform on snippet repositories. 

/cc @phikai

title: Update snippet fixtures to include repositories
description:
When we install from scratch GDK to start working on GitLab, we populate the database with some test data in order to have some working examples of different resources. One of the resources we create are `PersonalSnippets`.

At the moment, when we create those snippet test records, we aren't creating the associated repositories, leaving these records in an invalid state.

The problem with the GDK installation is that the associated components, Workhorse, Gitaly, the web server, ..., aren't running. Therefore, we cannot "commit" the snippet content and follow the existing workflow.

My proposal would be to:
1. Create a test snippet repository like [the one we use in other fixtures](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-test)
1. Once we create each snippet, we check its `.disk_path` inside the `repositories` folder, and clone a bare version of the former repository there.
  1. We need to check first what the deal with shards would be. Are we cloning the only on the `default` shard?
1. Update the associated db records, like `SnippetRepository`. Maybe calling `snippet.track_snippet_repository` can be enough
1. Update the snippet statistics

/cc @dsatcher @phikai

title: MR widget: add loading state with state transition on pipeline status
description:
This is a follow-up to MVC delivered in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/216048; the scope of this issue is item 2 in comment https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/216048#note_368874529.

## Problem to solve

When a merge request (MR) is submitted, there is no loading state that has transitions logic for the combination of scenarios based on these conditions:
- Is the setting `Pipeline must succeed` checked/enabled?
- Does the project have a pipeline configured (whether as external file or .gitlab-ci.yml)?
- How should the pipeline status impact merge request?

## Proposal

If no pipeline is found after X amount of time, then transition to a new state with appropriate message that replaces the message previously implemented in [gitlab #216048](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/216048).

New state should handle these scenarios:

| “Pipelines must succeed” | Pipeline exists (hasCi) | Pipeline status | Proposed text (expected UX) |
|---|---|---|---|
| enabled | yes (true) | succeeded | (no change to existing text) |
| enabled | yes (true) | not started/finished, failed, cancelled | Merge is only allowed once the pipeline has passed |
| enabled | no (false) | not found | Merge is only allowed once the pipeline has passed |
| **disabled** | no (false) | not found | (no change to existing text) |

## Possible solutions

(Summarized below is suggestion of [comment from gitlab #216048](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/216048#note_368685699))

When `Pipeline must succeed` is checked and `hasCi` is `false`, show a generic message `Unable to merge till pipeline succeeds` and link to explanation text that reason could be there is no CI, because external CI hasn't contacted us or because we are waiting for the runner to start the pipeline.

title: MR discussion diffs persists and reads too much data from Redis
description:
### Problem

During https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/scalability/-/issues/418#note_371299552 investigation I've noticed that `Projects::MergeRequestsController#discussions` is the top Redis `cache` reader (taking around 45% in the context of the top 3 actions), reading an average of 20gb per day.

Looking at the last 2 hours for instance, I can see a single project constantly reading _20MB_, taking 6 seconds avg for each request:

![Screen_Shot_2020-07-01_at_20.48.37](/uploads/79a4a9067d1ef4f0fdf142597ec67ea7/Screen_Shot_2020-07-01_at_20.48.37.png)
[source](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/8ed1ffbdda5bd32ccde730993f919003)

This negatively impacts our Redis cache instances considering we'll read as long as these MR discussions goes.

### Proposals

#### Persist in DB and Redis just what is needed

Currently we persist the discussion diff in the DB, then cache its highlighted version in Redis.

When persisting this diff we take everything [from very first line of the diff until the commented line](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/643322b4678265d75295d3b7c93ad89b35261203/lib/gitlab/diff/file.rb#L102). So imagine that if a MR has 200 comments in the middle of big files, we'll end up with a considerable amount of data persisted.

That happens because it's not simple to rebuild the diff file if it doesn't have the diff header ([see how we parse diffs](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/lib/gitlab/diff/parser.rb)). But, if we rebuild the diff with a custom header, trim every other line (leaving just a few, say, 5 lines in total) like we [do with suggestions](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/lib/gitlab/diff/suggestion_diff.rb#L21), then persist, we'll then be able to feed that into the same parser mentioned earlier. As an outcome:

1. Reduce the amount of data persisted in DB
2. Reduce the IO with Redis and DB
3. Improve response time in the process

#### Hard limit number of discussions

Currently we don't have limits for how much is loaded from `Projects::MergeRequestsController#discussions`, meaning that one could send an indefinite amount of discussions in MRs put pressure in a considerable amount of services at once.

### Status on Close

The original problem of persisting/reading too much data from Redis was mitigated by introducing compression. The long term challenge of being more efficient with the data (and then removing the need for compression) will be addressed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/247497.

title: Retrieve security dashboard URL used on Project Severity status report from backend - BE implementation
description:
The following discussion from !35031 should be addressed:

- [ ] @afontaine started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/35031#note_368958507):  (+2 comments)

    > Hmm I've never really seen us try to construct a URL to something in Vue. Is there anyway we can get this path from the backend? If not, can we pull it out into a function and save some of it as constants instead?


## Extra context

We have to construct the URL in the frontend since GraphQL misses this information. I believe the correct way to handle this should be to provide this information in GraphQL - for that reason I believe this task requires ~backend work.

Additional context from MR https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/35031#note_371695844
> A proper fix to this would be to actually include full dashboard URL within each `project` object under `severityGroup.projects`, but I think that will require some backend help.

### Implementation plan

1. Extend `Types::ProjectType` (`app/graphql/types/project_type.rb`) to have `security_dashboard_url` property.
2. Extend specs to account for the URL field

title: Possible Regression about "Reset approvals on push" does not reset approvals for re-opened MRs
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary
We're an enterprise customer seeing an issue where new pushes to an MR don't reset the approvals if the MR is closed at that time. This in theory allows circumventing the reset by: closing the MR -> pushing new code -> reopening the MR. All approvals will kept in that scenario.

It seems that this issue has come up in the past and has been reported fix, so this may be a possible regression. We're on GitLab Enterprise Edition 12.10.11-ee.

[This seems to be the original issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/1457), and [This MR claims to have fixed it](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/1051)


### Steps to reproduce

(same as previously found issue)

You need a minimum of 2 approvers, and separate user making and pushing changes to a branch.

1. User A opened a MR from branch X.
1. User B approved it.
1. User A closed MR.
1. User A pushed a commit to branch X.
1. User A reopened the MR.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?
Approvals are not reset, despite new code having been pushed

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?
Approvals should be reset

title: Publish HAR Recorder as it's own project
description:
API Fuzzing has a tool used to record web traffic and save it to a HAR file. HAR files can be used to perform API Fuzzing scans. The recording tool is currently published to the API Fuzzing package registry as `gitlab-apifuzzing-recorder` from the `api-fuzzing-src` project.

This tool should be open sourced as it is not dependent on the API Fuzzing code base and doesn't need to be in lockstep. This would facilitate public usage and feedback.

### Proposal

1. [x] Move source into it's own private repository (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/har-recorder)
1. [x] Create build script that
   1. Builds recorder
   1. Tests recorder
   1. Publishes recorder to API Fuzzing package registry
1. [x] Readme with 
   1. Basic usage of tool
   1. Installation process
   1. Shout out to `mitmproxy`
1. [x] Include MIT license
1. [x] Ping `@rnalen` once up for legal review
1. [x] Have Seth change to public

title: Group level PyPi Index for Python modules published across multiple projects
description:
### Problem to solve

GitLab 12.10 introduced the [GitLab PyPi Repository](https://gitlab.transzap.com/help/user/packages/pypi_repository/index.md) for storing Python modules in the GitLab Package Registry. I've been able to try this out successfully. But, I find the workflow really hard to manage when there is more than one project.

For example, I have two projects that have each published Python modules to their respective registries. Now, I want to use these published modules in a third project. I have to configure a separate repository or specify a separate index-url for each source project, because the repository endpoints are project specific.

Here's the Registry Setup verbiage provided in one of the projects. Note that the repository is specific to project ID `898`.

> If you haven't already done so, you will need to add the below to your .pypirc file.
> ```
> [gitlab]
> repository = https://gitlab.transzap.com/api/v4/projects/898/packages/pypi
> username = __token__
> password = <your personal access token>
> ```
> For more information on the PyPi registry, see the documentation.

Unlike the Docker container registry where users log in to a single point (`registry.gitlab.com` or equivalent) and then have access to images across multiple GitLab projects subject to role permissions, the Python PyPi repositories have individual access points per GitLab project.

The per-project repository endpoint is really burdensome to manage when I want to use modules in more than one GitLab project.

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)

### User experience goal

It should be possible to pull Python modules from multiple projects without specifying an index per project. Otherwise, module users have to know which project each module comes from by project ID, and manually manage a potentially long list of index URLs.

### Proposal

I would like a common repository endpoint that allows me to pull Python modules from multiple projects. This could be instance wide like the Docker registry, or at the group level.

### Further details

An install of three modules from three projects in the same group looks like this right now.

```
pip install \
    --extra-index-url https://$GITLAB_PYPI_INDEX_USERNAME:$GITLAB_PYPI_INDEX_PASSWORD@gitlab.transzap.com/api/v4/projects/897/packages/pypi/simple \
    --extra-index-url https://$GITLAB_PYPI_INDEX_USERNAME:$GITLAB_PYPI_INDEX_PASSWORD@gitlab.transzap.com/api/v4/projects/898/packages/pypi/simple \
    --extra-index-url https://$GITLAB_PYPI_INDEX_USERNAME:$GITLAB_PYPI_INDEX_PASSWORD@gitlab.transzap.com/api/v4/projects/899/packages/pypi/simple \
    dagster-aws-ext dagster-dask-ext dagster-pandas-ext
```

A hypothetical group-level index should allow me to install all three modules with one index URL.

```
pip install \
    --extra-index-url https://$GITLAB_PYPI_INDEX_USERNAME:$GITLAB_PYPI_INDEX_PASSWORD@gitlab.transzap.com/api/v4/groups/259/packages/pypi/simple \
    dagster-aws-ext dagster-dask-ext dagster-pandas-ext
```

### Permissions and Security

Access to the modules should still follow the project each module lives in, like how Docker images are handled.

### Documentation

### Availability & Testing

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

It should be easy to use modules from multiple projects published in GitLab PyPi package registries. Users should not have to manage multiple indexes.

### What is the type of buyer?

GitLab PyPi Repository is available in GitLab Silver/Premium.

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

### Links / references
https://gitlab.my.salesforce.com/0016100000KvacF

* [GitLab PyPi Repository](https://gitlab.transzap.com/help/user/packages/pypi_repository/index.md)

title: Handle Error for Missing Charts (No view YAML button) [FE]
description:
Part of &3711 

### Problem to Solve

* When defining dashboards by YAML, references to report pages could be accidentally mistyped and the only way to check them is at runtime. We need to help users understand when something has gone wrong and help them fix it.

### Proposal

* When a reference to a report page cannot be found, display an error in place of the chart which indicates which chart's report page slug was mistyped.

### Future Iteration

* The design shows a view YAML button. 
  * Will will add that button only after [users can create their own Dashboard pages](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3737).
  * When the user has write access to the file in which the chart is defined, link the button directly to the IDE for editing the file.
  * To do so use a URL such as `https://gitlab.com/-/ide/project/gitlab-org/gitlab/edit/master/-/README.md`
  * We can split this issue to handle the button depending on when we implement [users can create their own Dashboard pages](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3737).

If more context is required, see [this thread](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3711#note_371670108).

### Visual

![Screenshot_2020-07-01_at_15.24._2x](/uploads/455933372fbecf5f2cb23a2c1924010b/Screenshot_2020-07-01_at_15.24._2x.png)

title: See which commits and pipelines  are run in the fork project ref VS the parent project ref
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

When https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217451 is implemented it will be possible for project members (developer and up) to kick off a pipeline in the parent project based on the code of a forked project merge request.

This issue is scoped out of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217451 and intends to make it visible to see which commits and pipelines are run in the fork project ref VS the parent project ref. As we do not showcase these commits or pipelines differently in the merge request view.

In that view there is currently no indication of a ref they commits / pipelines are run on as it is assumed they will always run on the same ref (the merge request source branch).

| Screenshot   |
| --- |
| ![image](/uploads/756bbc8662dcf3f3076e37f1e5e82a28/image.png) |

### Intended users

<!-- Who will use this feature? If known, include any of the following: types of users (e.g. Developer), personas, or specific company roles (e.g. Release Manager). It's okay to write "Unknown" and fill this field in later.

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/

* [Dana (Data Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#dana-data-analyst)
-->

### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses? 
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 

It should be easy to figure out if a pipeline has been run on the parent project or on the fork project.

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

#### Acceptance criteria
- Pipelines run for a fork ref will receive a `fork` badge
- The badge is colored blue (info)
- The badge makes use of the new `small` [badge component](https://design.gitlab.com/components/badge)
- The fork badge will feature a tooltip with `Pipeline ran in fork of project`

title: Group issues by label within the iteration report
description:
## Problem

Many teams use labels to denote which team is responsible for which issue. When looking at an Iteration report, it is impossible to see issues that have my team's label. 

## Job Story

> when viewing an Iteration report from within a group, I want to see the issues grouped by labels, so that I can get a more accurate understanding of scope attributable to each label that has issues assigned to the given iteration.

## Proposal

- Include a "group by" selector above the issue list that allows me to select "labels".
- Show the issues grouped by their respective labels. 
- Allow the end-user to add/remove label(s) that they want to group issues by. 

## UX

[Figma Prototype](https://www.figma.com/proto/uLhGYebXKljzq7gyQGP7rM/225500-Group-issues-by-label-within-iteration-report?node-id=94%3A0&viewport=627%2C399%2C0.11019457876682281&scaling=min-zoom)

### Release notes

Issues within an iteration report can now be grouped by labels. This provides teams with a way to view progress during an iteration segmented by the many dimensions that labels are often used to represent.

title: Dashboards MVC Render a Single Chart [FE]
description:
Part of &3711

### Problem

Render a single chart on the dashboard as an incremental step.

### Proposal

* Render a single chart, full-width so we can avoid dealing with responsiveness and layout issues and focus on the API interaction.
* The API defined in [dashboards route and controller setup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/225429) provides a list of the Report Pages charts to render. 
* Display just the first chart in the list.
* Retrieve and render chart data in the same manner as Report Pages.
* Clicking on the chart title should link the user to the Report Page from whence it came.
* Ignore the back link in the image. 

### Visual

| Dashboard  | Report Page | 
| ------     | ------      |
| ![group-activity-dashboard-01](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/uploads/6db69088894e13f1a5cd0af1009992e7/group-activity-dashboard-01.png) | ![Group_recent_activity__issues_opened_mvc](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/uploads/1a95d33e1646ba35b807baed29c4886f/Group_recent_activity__issues_opened_mvc.png) |
| The dashboard page displays two charts side by side. The selection of charts is determined by a YAML file which references charts on report pages. **For this issue we will start with just one chart.** | One can click on the chart in the dashboard to drill-down to the corresponding report page. When the Report Page has a [data table](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220295) this will seem less odd. |

title: Retrieve security dashboard URL used on Project Severity status report from backend - FE implementation
description:
The following discussion from !35031 should be addressed:

- [ ] @afontaine started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/35031#note_368958507):  (+2 comments)

    > Hmm I've never really seen us try to construct a URL to something in Vue. Is there anyway we can get this path from the backend? If not, can we pull it out into a function and save some of it as constants instead?


## Extra context

We have to construct the URL in the frontend since GraphQL misses this information. I believe the correct way to handle this should be to provide this information in GraphQL - for that reason I believe this task requires ~backend work.

The file where we have a manual implementation is: `ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/first_class_vulnerability_severities.vue` and the line is this:

```
<gl-link target="_blank" :href="`/${project.fullPath}/-/security/dashboard`">{{project.nameWithNamespace}}</gl-link>
```

We basically need to fetch the endpoint from GraphQL and replace this line with the fetched data instead of manual URL construction.
